===Etymology 1===
{{etymid|en|luggage}}
{{root|en|ine-pro|*per- (fare)}}
From {{bor|en|frm|portemanteau||coat stand}}, from {{compound|frm|nocat=1|porter|alt1=porte|t1=carries|pos1=third-person singular present indicative of {{m|frm|porter|t=to carry}}|manteau|t2=coat|lit=[that which] carries coat}}.

====Noun====
{{en-noun|s|portmanteaux}}

# A large [[travel]]ling [[case]] usually made of [[leather]], and [[open]]ing into two [[equal]] [[section]]s.
#: {{alti|en|portemanteau|portmantua<q:obsolete>}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1667|author=w:Charles Croke|title=Fortune's Uncertainty|text=Rodolphus therefore finding such an earnest Invitation, embrac'd it with thanks, and with his Servant and '''Portmanteau''', went to Don Juan's; where they first found good Stabling for their Horses, and afterwards as good Provision for themselves.}}
#* {{RQ:Dickens Haunted House|page=7|column=2|chapter=The Mortals in the House|text=He brought down with him to our haunted house a little cask of salt beef; for, he is always convinced that all salt beef not of his own pickling, is mere carrion, and invariably, when he goes to London, packs a piece in his '''portmanteau'''.}}
#* {{RQ:Mansfield Bliss|page=71|passage=I believe that people are like '''portmanteaux'''—packed with certain things, started going, thrown about, tossed away, dumped down, lost and found, half emptied suddenly, or squeezed fatter than ever, until finally the Ultimate Porter swings them on to the Ultimate Train and away they rattle. . . .}}
# {{lb|en|Australia|dated}} A [[schoolbag]].
#: {{syn|en|port|school port}}
# {{lb|en|archaic}} A [[hook]] on which to [[hang]] [[clothing]].
#* {{RQ:Mansfield Bliss|page=72|passage=But before I started that long and rather far-fetched and not frightfully original digression, what I meant to say quite simply was that there are no '''portmanteaux''' to be examined here because the clientele of this café, ladies and gentlemen, does not sit down.}}

===Etymology 2===
{{etymid|en|word}}
First used by {{w|Lewis Carroll}} in ''{{w|Through the Looking-Glass}}'' to describe the words he coined in “{{w|Jabberwocky}}”.

====Adjective====
{{en-adj|-}}

# {{lb|en|attributive|linguistics}} Made by combining two (or more) words, stories, etc., in the manner of a linguistic portmanteau.
#* {{quote-journal|en|author=Nicholas Lezard|title=Spooky tales by the master and friends|work=The Guardian (London)|date=December 14, 2002|page=30|text=The overall narrator of this '''portmanteau''' story - for Dickens co-wrote it with five collaborators on his weekly periodical, ''All the Year Round'' - expresses deep, rational scepticism about the whole business of haunting.}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|date=December 11, 2002|author=Nick Bradshaw|title=One day in September|work=Time Out|page=71|text=We're so bombarded with images, it's a struggle to preserve our imaginations.' In response, he's turned to cinema, commissioning 11 film-makers to contribute to a '''portmanteau''' film, entitled '11'09"01' and composed of short films each running 11 minutes, nine seconds and one frame.}}

}}

#* {{quote-web|en|work=BBC|author=Nicholas Barber|date=July 12 2021|title=The French Dispatch: Four stars for Wes Anderson's latest|url=https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20210712-the-french-dispatch-four-stars-for-wes-andersons-latest|text=His long-awaited '''portmanteau''', which premiered in Cannes on Monday, is the most {{w|Wes Anderson|Anderson}} of all Anderson films. It's Anderson distilled, Anderson squared, Anderson to the nth degree.}}
